segments.text: Okay, so he took you out to Watts.
He showed me the condition and hired me, and it just was a miracle for me, because suddenly I have something to do.
I can go out to clear slums, and put the zeal I would have put into the Methodist ministry into slum clearance.
You can act on Christianity in a sound sound.
Oh, absolutely.
Monsignor O'Dwyer was really a practicing Christian.
So was my father.
But my father was ignorant.
He didn't know the real world.
O'Dwyer, through his charities, knew Los Angeles.
Within three years, we had a housing authority established.
We got the first projects built.
And then the housing authority segregated them.
one black, one brown, one white.
This is 1942.
There was no direction from the Supreme Court on the Constitutional question.
That didn't come until 54.
Even the Restrictive Covenant case didn't come down until 47.
And O'Dwyer and I talked it over and felt it was just morally wrong for the projects to be segregated.

And with the head of the League of Wimbledon, some liberal architects, and for the first time in our lives we set up a little picket line in front of the Housing Authority demanding that it integrate before it occupied.
And within a few days the Housing Authority gave in and agreed and came out to the sidewalk where we were standing and in very mean words
racist words, said they were going to integrate, and turned to O'Dwyer and said, who do you want to manage it?
And O'Dwyer said, let's try Frank.
So at the age of 28, from the picket line, I'm brought inside to become the manager of the first integrated housing project west of the Mississippi.
And this whole
thing that relates to the fact that it was that month, the first page, that we now have from the FBI.
The first surveillance on me was a memorandum written by J. Edgar Hoover in 1942, deterring me to be a potential security risk.
And from then on until 1980, everything in my life was orchestrated by the FBI, and I never knew it.
That's a turning point in this whole thing.
Maybe that's enough for you.
No, I want to continue, unless you're too tired.
I want to continue.
I just... Do you want to take a break for a minute?
No, I have the water.
Okay.
Would you... Times a quarter to three?
I'd rather get it done with.
Yeah, I'd like to... And rest my voice before I talk tonight.
Yeah.
Now, in Los Angeles, and in Watts, this Housing Council of Los Angeles, is this funded by public, private, or a combination of public and private funds?
The Housing Council under Monsignor O'Dwyer was a private citizen group.
Yeah, that's what I thought.
The Housing Authority of the City of L.A. was set up by the federal government and state governments.
It's a quasi-state corporation.
Yeah.
The funding came from the Wagner-Steagall Act of 1937, and from the Taft-Eleanor-Wagner bill of 1949.
Let me just respond to questions.
You wouldn't know any of this background, and you couldn't have questioned me on it, but now you know where I'm at.
Yeah.
You know the record a little bit from these other things.
Yeah.
Just let me respond to whatever you want.
Okay, well, I want you to explain how well integrated housing and wants in World War II worked.
What kind of problems did you have?
It worked perfectly.
We did not have problems.
We...
took people who had never had a flush toilet and gave them decent housing, and we completely overcame the argument that such people would turn the new housing into another slum.
The projects were gardens, and we not only did good housing, but we did a lot of education.
The Board of Education of L.A., for adult education for example, required
an average daily attendance, I think, of twelve students, in order to justify a teacher.
And I found out, when I'm managing these projects, that people would never come to a school or even the administration building for a class on, say, housekeeping, childcare.
But the projects were built around central courtyards, where there'd be about sixteen families.
And I got the Board of Education to allow a backyard, courtyard scene to be a classroom.
And then all the mothers would come into a given kitchen to get a teaching lesson on cooking or sewing or whatnot.
We became very, very much involved in basic education, political education.
We
I moved from the Ramona from the one project there in Watts.
By the way, when the Watts Rebellion came in 65.
I was going to ask you about that.
The only place that didn't burn on 103rd Street was that project.
That's interesting.
There's a more complicated story in that, but I'll come back to it.
I went up the ladder.
I moved to the Ramona Gardens, which is a very, very much larger project.
And I finally became assistant director of the Housing Authority in charge of the TAF program in 49, which gave us $110 million to spend.
And I was given the job of selecting the sites and selling them to the city council.
Yeah.
At Ramona Gardens, where we had about a third Hispanic and a third black,
we celebrated both Singletary Mile and Black History Week.
This would be in the 40s, long before there was any sense of black or Hispanic consciousness and pride.
We were doing it real, real early.
I got Orson Welles and Rita Hayworth to come to Ramona Gardens to celebrate Singletary Mile.
We had a Jewish
and a Mexican and a black co-chair of Cinco de Mayo.
And we tied it all together with the struggle against slavery in the States in the sixties.
It was all combined educationally.
The projects were beautifully maintained, and most of us in the work were committed.
We had a zeal.
It was not a nine-to-five job.
I finally moved into the project because I didn't want to be an absentee.
I wanted to live there at night.
I wanted my kids to be brought up in the same place where I was asking other people to bring up their kids.
So my kids were brought up in these projects in the old slum areas of L.A.
The thing about the Watts jumps your way ahead.
The influence we now know came from the FBI.
They were very conscious of what was happening to me, and were beginning to maintain surveillance on me in the projects.
We didn't know.
We're getting the documents now.
In 1952, without giving you all the circumstances,
the FBI was able to get me fired from the Housing Authority.
Yeah, we're going to talk about that.
I want to talk about that.
Let me just tell you the build-up on this thing.
You see, civil liberties problems were bad in this country, especially from 45 to 49 under Truman.
But we had
anti-communist oaths after the Smith Act of 1940.
I have an absolutely lousy civil liberties record.
I signed every loyalty oath they had.
I swore I was not a communist.
I each year took a special oath where we brought in the American Legion to stand with us with a battery of flags
sign or oath that we would never overthrow the government by force and violence, whatever the oaths were.
But by 1952, I had gone through changes.

I'd watched the Un-American Activities Committee destroy the motion picture people in LA, and school teachers, and some knowledge I had of labor, and I was getting more and more critical of this idea.
And I also was
ready to regurgitate, literally.

But once a year I suddenly have to prove I'm loyal by taking an oath and bringing in the L.A. Times to take a picture of me, signing, putting up my hand with the Legionnaires with their funny little hats.
And I was in an eminent domain for seniors where the FBI did it.

I was in an eminent domain proceeding on the necessity of taking Chavez Ravine, which is today the Dodger Ballpark, as the site for the larger project on the new ten thousand units that we were building.
Thirty-five hundred units.
It was designed by an architect friend that I live with, Richard Neutra, the most modern,
designed to make it beautiful in those hills above L.A. And I was the expert.
I knew all the correlations between bad housing and disease and delinquency, communicable disease, crime, the arguments you need to prove the necessity of taking private property for public use.
And I'd been through ten trials in L.A. We won them all.
And I was in one in August of 52.
I'd been on the stand for a day of direct and then a day of cross-examination.
And I knew every block.
I knew the statistic.
I was really professionally qualified to do what I was doing.
Suddenly the real estate
lawyers, owners, who were trying to block our access.
They didn't want it taken because they did not want minorities brought into that part of L.A. And the restrictive covenant ruling ended up only coming down in 1947.
And they called public housing socialized housing, creeping socialism, even though Senator Taft was the author.
All kinds of reasons.
And they were speculating on the land.
to turn it into luxury apartments.
And suddenly, in an ever-demanding proceeding, you've got to understand, hours, this block, that block, how do you know that?
Where do you get your information on rat infestation and so on?
They suddenly say, now, Mr. Wilkinson, would you please tell us all organizations, political or otherwise,
that you belonged to since 1931?
Totally irrelevant, immaterial question, except that was the summer of 1952.
The Korean War was then in its second year.
The Hollywood Ten were in jail.
Alger Hiss was a bad guy.
The Rosenbergs were due to be executed the following year.
Red hysteria.
Really hysteria.
And my lawyer had been a radical, or more radical, back at UCLA days.
In the 30s, probably.
And now had become a Republican.
And the Housing Authority, to protect itself, had hired all Republican law firms to represent us in the eminent domain proceeding.
So when the question came, he could only think of me as he knew me.
We'd never had any conversation about what had happened to me since.
And so he thought to challenge the question on relevancy would be bad public relations.
So he allowed me to answer.
And I qualified myself as an expert witness, where I trained professional societies I belonged to.
But then they pressed me, and now the political organizations, they didn't ask me, are you a communist?
The political organizations
And at that point, for the first time I reached that point, I said, I won't answer.
And then my lawyer objected.
And then the judge turned to the lawyer and said his objection was not timely.
And he turned to me and he said, I think you need a lawyer.
And I was suspended.
And suddenly all hell broke loose in L.A. because we now know
that J. Edgar Hoover, working with our chief of police, Parker, and with real estate interests, they were all working with Parker, had developed a dossier on me.
We never knew this.
And the dossier had been floating around town, and no one would touch it.
It went to our Republican mayor, and I was working with him around the clock.
I was five days on one telethon
in the Chamber of Commerce building with the mayor.
And they gave him this dossier.
The chief went in to see him.
And he looked at it and tore it up and said, I know this boy and I trust him.
Get out of here.
A year after I was suspended, Fletcher Bowen, this wonderful Republican mayor who I'd known as a child in my home

My father, you know, my father helped to elect him, part of a reform against the prostitution and the gambling interests of L.A. Two nights before his election in 1953, Chief Parker, on television, with a member of the Un-American Activities Committee, Washington, came in and on television they said, now tell us about the relationship between Frank Wilkinson and the mayor, and all this
public knowledge was brought out.
And then the dossier was brought out.
The first time I ever knew there was a dossier was nine months after it had been used.
And it was read on television.
I heard my dossier the first time read on television.
It was ridiculous stuff.
Today we laugh at it, but then it was scary.
Tell me some of the stuff.
I've been seen talking to a communist at the corner of 4th and Spring Street in Los Angeles that I had subscribed to the People's World newspaper.
Yeah.
All right.
Was any of it true?
I don't know about the communists at 4th and Spring Street.
I would think it probably was true.
And the subscription to the People's World, yes, it was true.
I subscribed to everything.
Yeah, so what?
So what?
At any rate, this was read, and then Chief Parker In that, were you called adid it say that you were a member of the communist power?
Nothing in there said that I was athe dossier didn't in any way suggest I had any communist connections.
I just associated
with the paper and people who were communists.
See, in the 1940s, communists were people.
They ran for office.
They were even part of our housing council.
All right.
They then described, Parker described how he took it to Bowron, and Bowron tore it up and threw it in the wastebasket and told him to get out of his office.
and this is all hammed up by the un-American guy.
And they said, really, really, really?
That's the man who's running for mayor tomorrow?
All right, the election, Bowron would have gone in with 80%.
He had a perfect record.
He got something like 36% of the vote.
And the new mayor came in, and within two weeks, turned over Chavez Ravine, where we had spent $7 million acquiring it.
in developing it, turned it over to Walter O'Malley and the Brooklyn Dodgers for a ballpark for four million.
One final point here that we'd forget if you just questioned me.
One thing about how I did get connected with the Un-American Activities Committee.
Yeah, we have to talk about that.
My connection with that was entirely an accident.
Unknowns to me, during the 40s, the Housing Authority, under a man named Howard Holsendorf, the executive director, had paid protection money to the California State Un-American Activities Committee.
You could buy protection.
A man named Hugh Burns was the state director, and he was given generous campaign contributions.
And then he kept
He prevented the Un-American Activities Committee from being attacked.
I never knew it.
Later I heard about this.
When I was suspended, there was a move to bring in the Federal Un-American Activities Committee to investigate the housing authority.

And because some of the right-wingers in L.A. knew of Olsendorf's connections with the State Committee and buying protection, Olsendorf called upon his friend in the State Committee to immediately hold a hearing on me to prevent the Federal Committee from coming in.
And more than that,
to get around the real estate people who were trying to bring in the Federal Committee to get rid of not me, but get rid of the Bolsendorf and the whole gang of them.
And for that matter, to attack the State Committee for taking payoffs to protect groups.
That I knew nothing about.
I had injured my kneecap in a television program with Mayor Bowen six weeks before that.
of these long televised programs, first years of television, were showing pictures of slums and talking about them to an audience.
And he said, Frank, where is that one of the certain kind he particularly wanted to show?
And it was in my briefcase across the room.
And I hurried
away from the camera to my briefcase to get that picture running back.
And when I squatted down on my knee to get it, I split the cartilage into my kneecap.
It's like football players get every weekend.
You can almost get it with microsurgery nowadays, you can almost be back playing in six weeks.
It was a little longer then.
The housing authority, not telling me that they were bringing the Un-American Committee in on me,

and yet feeling knowing i mean i had a marvelous record everybody i was very popular hundreds and hundreds of letters coming into the housing authority to defend me and the headlines for 30 days in l.a were just wild headlines red plot to rule housing something like that and the housing authority said
while we're working this thing all out, why don't you get your knee fixed?
Because I was on salary, and I was suspended.
So I checked into the Good Samaritan Hospital, Bolshevik Boulevard in L.A., same place where Bobby Kennedy died, and had surgery.
While I'm under sodium pentothal, this is now told to me by the nurse's doctor,
two federal or state or city police or marshal, somebody, people with badges, came to serve a subpoena on me in the hospital.
And they were just told that I'm under surgery.
And they waited outside of the surgery until I wheeled out in a gurney down a hallway into
sort of have a period where you get recovery room of some sort.
And they followed that in there and followed the nurses in there and said they wanted to talk to me as quick as they could.
And they said he's unconscious.
And they waited briefly and got impatient and went in, pushed the nurses aside and began to touch me on the shoulder and then shake me
And the nurses screamed, and I clearly remember the screaming voices of the nurses, and something bright shining in my face, which was the badges of these FBI police agents, whatever they were.
And they finally gave up.
They took a safety pin, one of the nurses, and pinned the subpoena from UAC on my surgical gown.
When I came out of recovery, I had been subpoenaed
appear before the Un-American Activities Committee.
I'm seventy-two now, and I'm traveling all over the country.
Eighty percent of my audiences are under twenty-five.
I'm trying to warn them about the revival
of the new Un-American Activities Committee called the Senate Judiciary Committee on Terrorism, the new buzzword.
And these students have no idea what the whole UAC was.
I know.
We abolished the Un-American Activities Committee in 75.
That 22 year old student on this campus was 11.
Yeah, I know.
And I'm also trying to warn people that under Reagan's new guidelines from the FBI, which superseded wonderful guidelines we got from Gerald Ford, after Watergate, the FBI was stopped.
Gerald Ford did it.
And we had that for six years.
Now under Reagan's guidelines, they put hidden microphones into undercover agents to go into the churches
Bible study classes in Arizona, in Tucson.
The old trial there, sanctuary movement, is based upon hidden microphones, intrusive techniques that Reagan guidelines allow.
I'm warning them about this, and telling the story about the old FBI.
They have no idea about, if you ask them who J. Ed Gruber was, that is fourteen years ago.
They were then eight.
You don't have to tell me.
All right, I'm just telling you a little bit.
I teach recent American history, and when I do, it's amazing.
It's amazing.
I teach McCarthyism and the Red Scare, and when I teach that, they look at me like I'm from the moon.
Right.
They can't believe the stories I hear.
By the way, I have a case.
You know I made a First Amendment challenge in the U.S. for ACLU?
out of Georgia in 1958.
I served a year.
Yeah, I know.
I want to get to that.
I want to get to that, but let's go first to 1953, Citizens Committee to Preserve American Freedoms.
All right.
But before we do that, I want to welcome you.
Okay.
Let's continue.
Now let's talk about the development of the Citizens Committee to Preserve American Freedoms.

organization founded in Los Angeles in 1952 in response to the repeated hearings in that area by both the federal and the state on American Activities Committee doing enormous damage to every aspect of cultural life in LA.
It was founded by the retired director of
of ACNU at that time, but also a retired minister, Reverend A.
A. Heist.
And it was a small group of liberals that did not think about abolishing these committees, but were trying to defend the victims.
When the hearings were held from then on, we tried to get the subpoenaed people together
before they fell apart and began thinking their best friend was an informer.
And help them get cheaper no-cost lawyers and develop public relations things that would improve community reaction to a UI hearing and maybe save jobs.
The best example I can give you is in 1956 when the committee came to L.A. and subpoenaed 56 members of the Musicians' Union.
There was always a reason.
Of course, they claimed they were investigating a law.
What was really going on is that there had been a Jim Crow local in Hollywood, and so the prime jobs went to whites.
killed it down, then the black musicians could get in.
And black and white unions, progressive unions, decided to have one local for all.
And they brought in UAC to kill off the anti-discrimination group.
When that happened, the Citizens Committee to Preserve American Freedoms had developed such a reputation.
Citizens were served, we'll say, on a Thursday morning at 7 a.m.
By that night, we had all 56 subpoenaed people in our office with an ACLU lawyer and some community support to talk how we could fight back.
The creativity that comes out of these meetings was unbelievable.
They found they had practically a full symphony orchestra amongst them except a piccolo player.
They decided the night before the hearing they'd have a symphony concert
made up entirely of subpoenaed musicians.
And they did.
They raised money to take a large hall seating sixteen hundred people, and they got a visiting cellist to come in and do a concerto.
And they took out two or three thousand dollars worth of ads in the LA Times and all the
The ad was a picture of an English horn, and then they had little Sherlock Holmes characters with spy glasses going around through the horns of the values, looking for spies.
And the ad was entitled, Force and Violins, and then come to the concert.
When that thing was over, not one musician lost their job.
Dorothy Chandler, wife of the editor of the LA Times, the main patron of the LA Symphony, her four favorite musicians, including her first oboist or something, were called.
And she defended them all, wouldn't allow any of them to be fired, because they were just fine musicians.
That's your question.
It was founded in 1952.
I was blacklisted.
I guess that's the word.
How did you find out that you were blacklisted?
Well, you get instant notice of that from the public that afternoon.
It was in August of 28.
For two months, the LA Times, Herald, all of them were just filled with these wild and scary headlines.
You would sometimes be interested in seeing a scrapbook of two months of headlines.
Every day, my picture, my name, everything was all over the papers.
And I became totally unemployable.
The Citizens Committee was founded in September of 52, but I had no connection with it.
I went until the spring of 53 without any kind of a job.
was called before the committee as a school teacher.
She taught social studies for 13 years in the LA City school system.
Very, very popular, very successful teacher.
And she was fired because she refused to answer questions of the committee on the grounds of husband-wife privilege conversations.
It was guilt by me, through me, that they got her out.
So we had no income coming in.

Finally, in June of 53, a Quaker family in Pasadena that owned a large department store called me and met me privately and arranged for me to be the sole janitor on a three-story department store that they had, coming in an hour after the store closed because they didn't think anyone should see me coming.
and I was not to tell anybody that I was working for them.
And they gave me a dollar an hour from six thirty in the night until four thirty in the morning to clean three, three floor hardwood departments.
All the showcases, sixteen toilets, vacuuming, the work.
Horrible, horrible, horrible experience for me.
The peak of my, my job at those
When I was fired, my job in today's money was around $65,000.
Yeah.
And then suddenly I'm dead.
I was getting a buck an hour to be a janitor.
At that point.
Why'd they hire you?
Quaker family.
Yeah.
Quakers were the best.
Robert Hutchins, Hallert Hoffman, the son of Paul Geoff, an Eisenhower's cabinet member.
Robert Hutchins of the former Chicago heard about me and came, they were active in the AFSC in Pasadena, and they came and helped me.
The YMCA of Hollywood refused to let my children go to summer camp that first summer.
My Sunday school superintendent came
He was the director of the YMCA, but he had been my assistant director.
My kids had gone every year for four years or whatever.
He came and said, they've been trying and trying, and he finally got a compromise.
They let my kids come if my wife and I would not bring them to the Y on Saturday morning, and if we would not come up the following Sunday to the campsite in the mountains for chapel services.
And if I'd get a private doctor to check them over, because the doctor at the Y said he would not see my kids.
At that point, the Quakers called me and offered me free family camp.
Very good attitude, the Quakers and Pasadena at that time.
I'm not giving you a card, but I'm just saying Quakers.
Nixon was a Quaker.

Anyway, in the summer of 1953, Reverend Heist and the new director of ACNU, Easton Monroe, and two or three other people, members of that Citizens Committee, came to me and said they wanted me to become the secretary of the Citizens Committee to Preserve American
to help defend the victims of UAC.
And I turned him down cold.
Said that anything I would touch, I'd destroy.
The committee could never be effective if I were any way associated with it.
And they argued exactly the opposite.
And took some arguing, because I really felt that.
was only when the ACLU director in this miniature really said they knew that my organizing skills would be just wonderful for it.
And they also felt that nobody knows what is a victim of UI, except the victim of UI.
Fight back.
So I went to work for them.
And that became my job.
Within two years, we turned it from just the victims to a long-range campaign to abolish.
And by 1960, we set up a national committee to abolish.
And in 1958, my reputation, the committee's reputation, but my personal reputation of being able to go into any town
and organized subpoenaed people into a fight back.
Became nationally known.
I was flying to Chicago, flying to Boston, flying to San Francisco, Gary, Indiana, and 20 I got a call to come down to Atlanta.
I'd never been in the South.
And I went down there to circulate a petition among church people, not to abolish UAC, but to keep it out of the South.
arguing that it was hard enough to have dialogue between black and white without having one side labeled a communist.
Sure.
Long answer, that's the answer.
That committee lasted up until we formed the National Committee to Avalanche Your Act.
And is that when, when you went to Atlanta, is that when you were cited for contempt of court?
August of 58.
It was at that time, we never knew how it happened.
I did not know I was going down to Atlanta until the day before.
Got a telegram, meet people in Atlanta, worked with Martin Luther King Sr. and others.
And I made a plane reservation, flew down, and it had been a minute after I checked into the hotel where they told me to come.
I was subpoenaed to appear before UI.
We thought it was just the Un-American Activities Committee following me, following everybody, everywhere.
And we learned just this last year that they had me under, they had eight agents following me from seven in the morning till ten at night, all my conversations wiretapped, everything.
They knew everything about where I was going, what I was doing, and were trying to disrupt my work.
The real disruption didn't begin until the early 60s.
The COINTELPRO of FBI didn't begin until 56.
In Georgia, it was 58.
At any rate, I made aACID wanted a witness.
They'd been trying for five years to get somebody who would not claim the privilege of the Fifth Amendment to make a First Amendment challenge.
And I had been looking.
No one was willing to do it because I was almost sure to go to jail.
we all felt that somebody should do it.
As a matter of conscience, we wanted the issue raised.
And there were some inklings in the dicta of some of the Warren Court decisions that implied that they might consider taking on the Un-American Activities Committee on First Amendment grounds.
Go ahead.
And so you were subpoenaed in front of HUAC.
Now, originally, you were down there to help with the beginnings of the civil rights program, correct?
First time I ever went to Georgia, first time I ever went to the South, was when I came down in July of 58 and was subpoenaed.
The civil rights thing in Montgomery had begun in 54.
Yeah, right.
From then on, I became involved in the Civil Rights program in the South, but all in connection with the way the Un-American Activities Committee was being used as a bulwark for segregation.
Right, right.
Martin King, there's a picture of us together there, that's at Morehouse College.
After the court decision came down and we'd exhausted our appeals and we were going to jail, he and Coretta King had a reception for Carl and me at Morehouse College the night before we went to jail.
And 400 black leaders were sat out there to honor us as we went to jail.
And I don't think I've ever seen the newspaper clipping on it.
because I went right into jail.
But his statement was extremely important historically.
He said that we're honoring these men.
He said, these men are going to jail for us.
We will never achieve peaceable integration in the South until the Un-American Activities Committee has been abolished.
And then we went on to jail.
When I was in jail, he and Reinhold Niebuhr and others started a petition for clemency to get us out, which Kennedy denied while we were in.
On what grounds?
Kennedy was no good.
The Secretary of the World Council of Churches
Chicago was his name, took this petition, launched by Martin Luther King, Jr., Reinhold Niebuhr, A.J.
Muste, Dean John Bennett, Union Theological Seminary, really top, top people.
Howard Schomer, S-C-H-O-M-E-R, your record will be the first time it's accurate.
He was secretary of the World Council of Churches.
He was on his way to New Delhi for a World Church Conference.
He delayed it to deliver these 3,500 names to President Kennedy.
And when he went down there to see him, Kennedy would not even meet the delegation, turned it over to his pardon attorney, who immediately rejected it.
And of course, we now know the records, you see.
The moment I went into jail,
The FBI's whole apparatus on me went into prison with me.
They just sent me, two months ago, every letter that I wrote and every letter I received while I was in prison.
These were all part of the file.
They had surveillance on me.
And we were moved around from prison to prison to prison as terrible harassment as political prisoners.
The pressure on the Kennedys, Bobby and Jack, from the FBI was enormous there.
Why do you think that was?
I think Hoover, first of all, Hoover had no real mandate to do what he was doing.
It was just something sort of an accretion, a collection of
power given to him at the budget hearings each year, beginning with Harlan Stone back in 1924 through Roosevelt.
And Hoover had adverse information on the sex and the financial, every kind of
dealing that would either be illegal, or corrupt, or immoral, or bad PR.
He had it on them all.
When I, the decision came down in the 60th term of the court, beginning of 58, take your time, February 28th, my attorneys, Roland Watts, the National ACNU, and Nanette Dembitz, who was
The niece of Justice Brandeis, who was writing the briefs on my case, they filed appeal after appeal to delay my jailing as long as they could.
